title.value: Herbarium collections remain essential in the age of community science
title.justification: The title provides a clear indication of the paper's focus on the importance of herbarium collections in the context of community science efforts.
title.quote: Herbarium collections remain essential in the age of community science

extractions.description: The paper discusses the importance of herbarium collections compared to community science platforms like iNaturalist in capturing biodiversity data. It assesses how herbarium specimens and community science observations represent the diversity, distributions, and modeling needs of vascular plants in Canada. The results suggest that herbarium specimens, despite being fewer in number, capture more diversity and environmental niches than iNaturalist observations, emphasizing the need for digitizing existing herbarium collections to enhance biodiversity modeling.

type.justification: The paper involves the analysis of data from herbarium specimens and iNaturalist observations to compare their effectiveness in capturing biodiversity details.
type.quote: Here, we compare how well community science (iNat-uralist) observations and digitized herbarium specimens represent the diversity, distributions, and modeling needs of vascular plants in Canada.

name.justification: The research focuses on improving biodiversity data capture and modeling, which are key areas within Biodiversity Informatics.
name.quote: Overcoming these critical data shortfalls will rely on obtaining additional biodiversity data that captures the diversity and distribution of life on Earth.

name.justification: The paper deals with species distribution models to predict species occurrence based on biodiversity data.
name.quote: Species distribution models (SDMs), which predict species occurrence across geographic space and time based on abiotic and biotic predictors, are increasingly used for this purpose.

name.justification: The paper discusses the use of SDMs to predict species occurrence based on biodiversity data.
name.quote: Species distribution models (SDMs), which predict species occurrence across geographic space and time based on abiotic and biotic predictors, are increasingly used for this purpose.

is_contributed.justification: The paper references the use of SDMs but does not claim to contribute a new model in this field.
is_contributed.quote: Species distribution models (SDMs), which predict species occurrence across geographic space and time based on abiotic and biotic predictors, are increasingly used for this purpose.

is_executed.justification: The paper involves using SDMs for analyzing biodiversity data from herbarium specimens and iNaturalist observations.
is_executed.quote: Species distribution models (SDMs) were used to describe and quantify biodiversity.

is_compared.justification: While SDMs are used, the paper does not explicitly compare different SDM approaches or algorithms.
is_compared.quote: ... and so it remains unclear how the accumulation of additional iNaturalist observations versus the digitization of existing herbarium specimens might improve our ability to describe, quantify, and model biodiversity.

referenced_paper_title.value: 30×30 biodiversity gains rely on national coordination
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper appears to build context around SDMs, biodiversity, and the effects of data accumulation on improving species distribution models.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Eckert, I., Brown, A., Caron, D., Riva, F. & Pollock, L. J. 30×30 bio-diversity gains rely on national coordination.

name.justification: The paper evaluates the data from iNaturalist in comparison with herbarium records.
name.quote: While community science platforms like iNaturalist favor common and larger species and urban areas.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper does not cite a specific reference paper for iNaturalist data specifically.

name.justification: The paper uses GBIF dataset to analyze biodiversity data from Canada and the United States.
name.quote: For all of Canada’s 4392 vascular plant species, we downloaded observation data from GBIF for Canada and the United States from the year 1900 to present (January 2024)

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper directly references GBIF download as the source for biodiversity data used in its analysis.
referenced_paper_title.quote: GBIF.org. Occurrence Download. 1380345621 The Global Biodiversity Information Facility https://doi.org/10.15468/DL.6FJT8Y

name.justification: The paper uses R for statistical analyses and modeling tasks related to the study.
name.quote: We fit Boosted Regression Trees (BRTs) with all environmental, topographic, and soil predictors in the “dismo” package for R.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper does not cite a specific reference paper for R but mentions its use for the analysis.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Packages for R are mentioned throughout the analysis.
